conclusion: The problem involves understanding how shadows labeled A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves backward above the objects.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their position and size depend on the position of the light source and the object.
If the light source is far away, shadows are straightforward, with objects closer to the light source casting longer shadows.
The light source is above the objects and moving backward, suggesting it is not too far away.
Picture 1 shows four objects: a sandal (A), a cake (C), some dice (R), and a feather (D), each casting shadows labeled A, C, R, and D respectively.
The shadows in Picture 1 are cast behind the objects, indicating the light source is positioned at the front.
